= Configuring Build Path =

  # Download the latest Infinitum distribution from the [http://code.google.com/p/infinitum-framework/downloads/list Downloads] page.
  # Extract the JAR files from the zip archive (there are three you need -- infinitum-_version_.jar and the two dependencies in `lib`)  and place them in your application's `libs` directory.
  # Verify that the JARs have been added to the application's build path (in Eclipse: right-click on the project > Build Path > Configure Build Path)
Your project can now reference Infinitum Framework APIs.

= Framework Configuration =

Before Infinitum can be used, you must create a configuration file, `infinitum.cfg.xml` and place it in your application's `res/xml` directory. Below is an example template that can be used with minimal configuration. See the InfinitumCfgXml guide for more information on configuring the framework.

{{{
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<!DOCTYPE infinitum-configuration PUBLIC
"-//Infinitum/Infinitum Configuration DTD 1.0//EN"
"http://clarionmedia.com/infinitum/dtd/infinitum-configuration-1.0.dtd">

<infinitum-configuration>

    <application>
        <property name="debug">true</property>
    </application>
    
    <sqlite>
        <property name="dbName">myDb</property> 
        <property name="dbVersion">1</property>
    </sqlite>
    
    <rest>
        <property name="host">http://localhost/webservice</property>
    </rest>
    
    <domain>
        <model resource="com.example.domain.Foo" />
    </domain>

</infinitum-configuration>
}}}

The framework must be configured within the application code before any of its classes may be used. Within your `Activity`, call the following code:

{{{
ContextFactory.getInstance().configure(this);
}}}

This will configure Infinitum using the `infinitum.cfg.xml` file in `res/xml`. Alternatively, you can specify explicitly which configuration resource to use by doing the following:

{{{
ContextFactory.getInstance().configure(this, R.xml.infinitum);
}}}
